summary: This is an email from an Assistant U.S. Attorney in the Southern District of New York, dated June 24, 2019, discussing the covert investigation into Jeffrey Epstein for sex trafficking of minors in New York. The email focuses on coordinating victim outreach and compliance with victims' rights obligations, referencing the prior Florida investigation's failures.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The billionaire under investigation for paying dozens of minor girls to engage in sex acts with him at his Manhattan mansion.

events.title: Email Coordination on Epstein Investigation
events.description: An Assistant U.S. Attorney emails to coordinate victim outreach strategies for the upcoming prosecution of Jeffrey Epstein, referencing the need to comply with victims' rights obligations.

events.title: Prior Florida Investigation and Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Reference to a previous Florida investigation into Jeffrey Epstein that resulted in a non-prosecution agreement, and where the U.S. Attorney's Office was found to have violated victims' rights.

events.title: Upcoming New York Charges
events.description: The prosecution team expects to charge Jeffrey Epstein in New York in the next week or so for conduct involving dozens of minor victims at his Manhattan mansion.

keyFacts: The Southern District of New York was actively investigating Jeffrey Epstein in June 2019 for sex trafficking of minors in New York, specifically at his Manhattan mansion.
The investigation was covert and confidential, with the prosecution team already in touch with victims in New York and Florida.
The email explicitly states an expectation to charge the case within the next week.
A major concern was complying with victims' rights obligations, citing a federal court finding that the U.S. Attorney's Office violated those rights during the prior Florida investigation.
The prosecution team was strategizing on how to handle potential victim outreach, considering directing victims to contact them directly rather than the FBI due to sensitivity over past failures.
